currentUpdates.title: 14m unfair motor loans due compensation under FCA-proposed scheme
currentUpdates.summary: Payouts on an expected 14m unfair motor finance agreements could start next year, under an industry-wide compensation scheme proposed by the FCA. The FCA estimates people would receive around £700 per agreement, on average. Based on the number of consumers the FCA estimates could take part in the scheme, lenders could pay out £8.2 billion in compensation.Motor finance companies broke laws and regulations in force at the time by failing to disclose important information. This led to unfairness, with consumers denied the chance to negotiate or find a better deal and, in some instances, paying more for their loan. A compensation scheme is the best, most efficient way of getting compensation to those owed it and would make it simpler for those who would otherwise struggle to claim. Research commissioned by the FCA shows almost half of those aware of possible compensation, but who had not yet made a claim, (46%) cite a lack of clarity on whether a claim would be eligible as a barrier, and n

currentUpdates.title: FCA consults on motor finance compensation scheme
currentUpdates.summary: We are consulting on an industry-wide scheme to compensate motor finance customers who were treated unfairly between 2007 and 2024. A compensation scheme is the best way to ensure consumers who have lost out receive fair compensation in an orderly, consistent, quick, and efficient way, while ensuring a well-functioning and competitive motor finance market.An alternative to a compensation scheme would require consumers to complain to firms, then to the Financial Ombudsman Service if dissatisfied with the firm’s response, or through the courts. This would result in significantly higher administrative and legal costs for firms and consumers, lengthy delays and uncertain outcomes for all involved.Why are we proposing a scheme?Many firms broke laws and regulations in force at the time by failing to disclose important information. Our extensive review, covering data from 32m agreements, found widespread failures to adequately disclose the existence and nature of commission and contractual ti

currentUpdates.title: ESMA organises its first Data Day focused on burden reduction and digitalisation
currentUpdates.summary: ESMA organises its first Data Day focused on burden reduction and digitalisation 07 October 2025   Market data  The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), the EU’s financial markets regulator and supervisor, is announcing the first ESMA Data Day to be held on 2 December 2025. This flagship event will showcase how smarter data use and digitalisation can simplify the regulatory framework and reduce reporting burdens while steering clear of deregulation.  Under the theme “Burden Reduction in the Digitalisation Era”, the Data Day will bring together regulators, market participants, and data experts to explore how simplification and digitalisation can go hand in hand. The programme will feature sessions on:   Approaches to achieving simplification and burden reduction  Streamlining compliance and reassessing regulatory requirements  Leveraging technology for efficient data management  Future trends and strategic priorities in data usage and governance   Both on-site and online pa

currentUpdates.title: Currency Matters Limited enters special administration
currentUpdates.summary: On 6 October 2025, Currency Matters Limited entered special administration under the Payment and Electronic Money Institution Insolvency Regulations 2021. Frank Ofonagoro and Allister Manson of Opus Business Advisory Group were appointed as joint special administrators. Currency Matters is authorised by the FCA to provide payment services to corporate and retail clients.On 1 September 2025, we imposed restrictions on Currency Matters on undertaking certain activities. A full description of the restrictions can be found on the Financial Services Register. The directors of Currency Matters concluded that the firm was insolvent and applied to court for a special administration order. The special administrators are responsible for managing customer claims against the firm and returning funds to customers where possible.If you have any questions regarding the special administration process, please contact the special administrators directly by emailing currencymatters@opusllp.com. For more

currentUpdates.title: Publication of the first single volume cap data
currentUpdates.summary: Publication of the first single volume cap data 07 October 2025   Market data Trading  The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), the EU’s financial markets regulator and supervisor, will publish on 9 October at 18:00h the first results for the “single” volume cap mechanism (VCM).  The new “single” VCM limits at 7% the trading volume under the reference price waiver in the EU, compared to the total aggregated trading volume in the EU over the last 12 months for each equity and equity-like financial instrument. If the limit is exceeded, trading venues will need to suspend the use of the waiver for the concerned instrument for a period of three months. Trading venues must base their decision to suspend the waiver use on the data published by ESMA under the dedicated VCM webpage.  As a reminder, the previous double volume cap no longer applies.   Further information: Cristina Bonillo Olivares Senior Communications Officerpress@esma.europa.eu

currentUpdates.title: Daniel Pugh sentenced to 7 and a half years in prison for £1.3m Ponzi scheme
currentUpdates.summary: Daniel Pugh has been sentenced to 7 years and 6 months in prison for running a £1.3m Ponzi scheme, following a prosecution brought by the FCA. Pugh, aged 35, set up a Ponzi scheme with another individual that netted over £1m. Run from his bedroom in Devon, the fraudulent Imperial Investment Fund (IIF) took money from 238 investors Pugh targeted largely through Facebook adverts. Investors were offered impossibly high returns of 1.4% a day, 7% a week or 350% a year.Pugh received £96,000 from the scheme. He used the money to support his lifestyle, including designer clothes, restaurants and withdrawing £18,000 in cash.The returns investors were promised did not materialise. Pugh duped investors into believing he was successfully trading and their money was safe. Even at the point he knew the scheme was collapsing, Pugh continued to try to attract more investors into the scheme.Steve Smart, executive director of enforcement and market oversight at the FCA, said:'Pugh made outlandish claims

currentUpdates.title: EU Supervisory Authorities warn consumers of risks and limited protection for certain crypto-assets and providers
currentUpdates.summary: EU Supervisory Authorities warn consumers of risks and limited protection for certain crypto-assets and providers 06 October 2025   Digital Finance and Innovation Investor protection Joint Committee Warnings and publications for investors  The European Supervisory Authorities (EBA, EIOPA and ESMA – the ESAs) today issued a warning to consumers, reminding that crypto-assets can be risky and that legal protection, if any, may be limited depending on which crypto-assets they invest in. This warning is accompanied by a factsheet explaining what the new EU regulation on Markets in Crypto-Assets (MiCA) means for consumers. The ESAs recommend concrete steps consumers can take to make informed decisions before investing in crypto-assets, such as checking if the provider is authorised in the EU.  Since December 2024, MiCA applies to certain types of crypto-assets and establishes a consistent supervisory regime at both national and European level for issuers and providers of crypto-assets servic

currentUpdates.title: Regulators join forces to tackle poor claims management practices
currentUpdates.summary: The FCA, Solicitors Regulation Authority (SRA), Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) and the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) are joining together to tackle misleading advertising and inadequate information provided by some claims management companies (CMCs) and law firms working on motor finance claims, and the risk that excessive fees are charged to clients. Alison Walters, director, consumer finance, at the FCA, said:'Misleading advertising and inadequate disclosure have meant that people are signing contracts with some firms without the facts. When they try to exit, they face high fees. We’re acting where we see bad practice and, through our own advertising, we’re ensuring consumers can make informed choices.'Paul Philip, chief executive of the SRA, said:'The risks and issues facing consumers in this area of the market are unprecedented, and we are using all the levers at our disposal to protect consumers, identify poor practices and hold law firms to account.'Usingpowers u

previousUpdates.title: ESMA 2026 Work Programme – advancing on more integrated, accessible and competitive financial markets in the EU
previousUpdates.summary: ESMA 2026 Work Programme – advancing on more integrated, accessible and competitive financial markets in the EU 03 October 2025   About ESMA Financial reporting Investor protection Press Releases  The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), the EU’s financial markets regulator and supervisor, has today published its 2026 Annual Work Programme.  Guided by its multi-annual strategy for 2023–2028 which sets out three strategic priorities and two thematic drivers, ESMA’s 2026 work programme focuses on delivering on core policy and supervisory mandates while contributing to ambitious reforms for more integrated, accessible, and innovative EU capital markets. Verena Ross, Chair of ESMA, said:  “A core focus in 2026 is ESMA’s ambitious, and at the same time pragmatic, approach to simplification and burden reduction. We are pursuing a holistic strategy to streamline rules, enhance risk-based supervision and ensure proportionate reporting requirements across the ESMA remit.  In that s

previousUpdates.title: The FCA and Practitioner Panel 2024/25 survey findings
previousUpdates.summary: The FCA and the Practitioner Panel have published a report from our 2024/25 joint survey of FCA regulated firms. We have published the findings of the FCA and Practitioner Panel 2024/25 survey (PDF).The survey feedback gives us a clear picture of how firms see the FCA’s performance and are an important tool to help us focus on the issues that matter most.Feedback shows that firms’ views are broadly similar with previous years. Most continue to hold a positive perception of our performance (rated us 7 out of 10 for satisfaction) and trust (81% said trust levels had stayed the same as the previous year) in our role to deliver strategic priorities and maintain the integrity of financial markets.Matt Hammerstein, chair of the FCA Practitioner Panel said:'These results highlight both the progress the FCA has made and the areas where further improvement is needed. It is encouraging that trust levels, along with perceptions of staff knowledge and experience, have remained steady, and many of

previousUpdates.title: ESMA provides updated instructions for weekly commodity derivative position reporting
previousUpdates.summary: ESMA provides updated instructions for weekly commodity derivative position reporting 25 September 2025   Trading  The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has published updated reporting instructions and XML schema (version 1.2.0) for the weekly reporting of commodity derivatives positions under the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive II (MiFID II), reflecting the changes from the latest review.  Beyond the changes directly originating from MiFID II – such as the requirement to publish two weekly reports and the exclusion of (spot) emission allowances from position reporting – the updated XML schema and reporting instructions also include other amendments to ITS 4, like the harmonisation of reporting units for energy derivatives. The adjustments are based on ESMA’s Final Report submitted to the European Commission in December 2024, which is currently pending adoption. ESMA has opted for this approach to ensure a consistent reporting framework and minimise the need f

previousUpdates.title: Tax-free pension lump sums and cancellation rights
previousUpdates.summary: Our statement explaining how FCA rules on cancellation rights, to complement an HMRC statement about how tax legislation applies to tax-free pension lump sums. On 25 September 2025, HMRC published newsletter 173 which explains how:tax legislation applies to tax free lump sums andthe tax implications when lump sums are returned to pensionsTo support firms' understanding of that statement, we are providing an explanation of how our existing rules on cancellation rights operate in these scenarios.Under our rules, consumers have the right to cancel certain contracts, typically within 30 days of entering the contract, if they change their mind.However, the right to cancel does not arise in all circumstances. A consumer accessing tax-free cash in itself does not trigger cancellation rights under our rules.Our rules do not exempt firms from HMRC requirements. This means firms should be mindful how they structure their contracts in light of the interaction between HMRC requirements and ours.FC

previousUpdates.title: Update on appointing a bond consolidated tape provider
previousUpdates.summary: We have received a legal challenge to our decision to award the contract for the bond consolidated tape provider. In response, we said:'We undertook a fair, competitive 2-stage process to ensure the provider could deliver a high-quality tape and the best value for money. 'This challenge means we can’t enter into a contract with the successful bidder as quickly as planned. We will do so as soon as possible and, in the meantime, continue discussions with market participants to prepare for the tape.'

previousUpdates.title: Beware of high-risk investments from unregulated firms
previousUpdates.summary: We are concerned people are being encouraged to invest in high-risk schemes offered by unregulated firms without appreciating the risks involved. Many of the firms offering these products don’t need to be authorised by the FCA, as they rely on exemptions in the law that take them out of our remit.If a firm offering an investment is not regulated by the FCA there are generally far fewer protections. For example, you are unlikely to be able to take complaints to the Financial Ombudsman Service and you’re unlikely to be able to make a claim through the Financial Services Compensation Scheme. That may make it much harder to get your money back if something goes wrong.Some of the particularly risky products we’ve seen have been unlisted loan notes or mini-bonds.Unlisted loan notes or mini-bonds come in several forms and are often used to finance property developments. This involves an investor lending money, often via a third-party firm, to fund property developments. While all investments

previousUpdates.title: Regulatory perspective and priorities for 2025
previousUpdates.summary: Speech by Lucy Castledine, director of consumer investments, at the Personal Investment Management   Financial Advice Association (PIMFA) Compliance Conference 2025. Speaker: Lucy Castledine, director, consumer investmentsEvent: PIMFA Compliance Conference 2025Delivered: 25 September 2025Note: this is the speech as drafted and may differ from the delivered version.Reading time: 18 minutesKey messages:We want to challenge ourselves to be a smarter regulator and engage with you so we can raise standards together.Input into our proposals on targeted support and simplified advice – these will define the future for decades to come. Firms should continue to challenge themselves on Consumer Duty and how best to make sure clients have good outcomes.When firms see illegal content online, and have challenges reporting this content to tech platforms, let us know.

artifacts.narrative:
Why This Week Matters

This week's regulatory updates cover a range of significant developments across the financial services sector, from compensation schemes for unfair motor finance agreements to new guidance on crypto-asset regulation and market infrastructure changes. These updates signal an active regulatory environment focused on consumer protection, market integrity, and enabling innovation.

The Big Picture

The updates this week reflect the FCA's ongoing efforts to ensure fair outcomes for consumers, with the proposed motor finance compensation scheme being a key focus. Regulators are also working to enhance the crypto-asset regulatory framework and promote smarter, more efficient data management and reporting. Additionally, the Bank of England and ESMA are making changes to market infrastructure, such as the switch to a single volume cap mechanism and updates to the IFRS taxonomy.

What Changed Since Last Week

This week's updates build on previous regulatory actions, such as the FCA's ongoing work on consumer protection and the Bank of England's efforts to manage foreign currency reserves. The new developments include the FCA's launch of a £1 million awareness campaign for the motor finance compensation scheme, ESMA's publication of the first single volume cap data, and the FRC's consultations on enhancing auditing standards and enforcement procedures.

Key Storylines

1. Consumer Protection: The FCA's proposed motor finance compensation scheme and associated awareness campaign demonstrate the regulator's commitment to ensuring fair outcomes for consumers who were treated unfairly by lenders. This aligns with the FCA's broader focus on the Consumer Duty and improving financial inclusion.

2. Crypto-asset Regulation: The EU Supervisory Authorities' warning to consumers about the risks and limited protections for certain crypto-assets highlights the ongoing regulatory efforts to establish a consistent supervisory regime for this evolving market segment.

3. Market Infrastructure: The changes to the volume cap mechanism and IFRS taxonomy signal ESMA and the Bank of England's work to enhance the efficiency and transparency of financial markets, supporting the broader goals of market integration and innovation.

4. Regulatory Simplification and Burden Reduction: Initiatives such as ESMA's Data Day and the FCA's continued efforts to streamline data reporting requirements demonstrate the regulators' focus on reducing unnecessary burdens on firms while maintaining effective oversight.

Looking Ahead

The regulatory landscape continues to evolve, with a focus on consumer protection, market integrity, and enabling innovation. Firms should expect further developments in areas such as crypto-asset regulation, sustainability-linked financing, and the ongoing simplification of compliance requirements. Engagement with regulators and staying informed on these key storylines will be crucial for firms to navigate the changing environment effectively.

new_themes.summary: The Bank of England is continuing its work on central bank digital currency (CBDC), with the CBDC Academic Advisory Group meeting in June 2025.

The European Supervisory Authorities have issued a warning to consumers about the risks and limited protections for certain crypto-assets and providers, in light of the new EU regulation on Markets in Crypto-Assets (MiCA).

new_themes.topic: Compensation schemes for unfair motor finance agreements
new_themes.summary: The FCA is consulting on an industry-wide compensation scheme to compensate motor finance customers who were treated unfairly between 2007 and 2024, with an estimated 14 million consumers eligible for payouts.

accelerating.summary: There are several updates related to customs and international trade regulation, including guidance on the Customs Declaration Service, duty deferment accounts, and codes for identifying locations for customs examinations.

The FCA, FRC, and ESMA are all actively consulting on and updating various aspects of financial services regulation, including the Economic Crime Levy, claims management practices, auditing standards, and corporate reporting.

resolving.topic: Compensation for unfair motor finance agreements
resolving.summary: The FCA is consulting on an industry-wide compensation scheme to compensate motor finance customers who were treated unfairly between 2007 and 2024.

The European Supervisory Authorities have issued a warning to consumers about the risks and limited protections for certain crypto-assets and providers, in light of the new EU regulation on Markets in Crypto-Assets (MiCA).

shifting_focus.topic: Diversity, equity, and inclusion in financial services
shifting_focus.summary: The UK remains steadfast in its commitment to advancing the Women, Peace and Security agenda globally, as highlighted in a statement at the UN Security Council.
shifting_focus.notes: This update suggests a shifting focus towards diversity, equity, and inclusion in the financial services sector.

shifting_focus.summary: The UK has applied sanctions on over 70 Iranian individuals and organizations linked to Iran's nuclear program, and is also involved in international efforts to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, as evidenced by statements on Afghanistan and the High-Level Financing Event for the African Union Support and Stabilisation Mission in Somalia.
shifting_focus.notes: These updates indicate a continued focus on sanctions and anti-money laundering efforts.

correlations.summary: There are several updates related to customs and international trade regulation, including guidance on the Customs Declaration Service, duty deferment accounts, and codes for identifying locations for customs examinations.
correlations.notes: These updates suggest a continued focus on customs and international trade regulation, likely in response to changes in trade policies and requirements.

correlations.summary: The FCA, FRC, and ESMA are all actively consulting on and updating various aspects of financial services regulation, including the Economic Crime Levy, claims management practices, auditing standards, and corporate reporting.
correlations.notes: These updates suggest a continued focus on financial services regulation, likely in response to emerging risks and the need to maintain the integrity of the financial system.

artifacts.onePager:
Executive Summary
The key developments this week include the UK Upper Tribunal handing down a significant judgment on Clearview AI Inc, the FCA consulting on an industry-wide motor finance compensation scheme, and ESMA organizing its first Data Day focused on burden reduction and digitalisation in financial services.

Critical Actions Required
- Monitor the Clearview AI Inc judgment and assess the implications for the firm's data protection and facial recognition practices.
- Engage with the FCA's consultation on the proposed motor finance compensation scheme and prepare for its implementation.
- Participate in ESMA's Data Day event to stay informed on regulatory priorities around simplification and digitalisation.

Key Regulatory Developments
Significant Impact:
- Clearview AI Inc judgment by UK Upper Tribunal on data protection and facial recognition
- FCA consultation on industry-wide motor finance compensation scheme

Moderate Impact:
- Prime Minister's trade mission to India
- ESMA's first Data Day on burden reduction and digitalisation
- Currency Matters Limited enters special administration
- Publication of first single volume cap data by ESMA

Business Implications
The Clearview AI Inc judgment, FCA motor finance compensation scheme, and ESMA's digitalisation initiatives will have wide-ranging impacts across the financial services sector, particularly for firms in fintech, banking, investment management, and payment services. Firms should closely monitor these developments and prepare to adapt their practices accordingly.

Recommended Next Steps
1. Review the Clearview AI Inc judgment and assess the firm's data protection and facial recognition practices, making necessary adjustments.
2. Participate in the FCA's consultation on the motor finance compensation scheme and prepare for its implementation.
3. Engage with ESMA's Data Day event to stay informed on regulatory priorities and explore opportunities for simplification and digitalisation.
4. Monitor other key regulatory updates, such as the Bank of England's foreign currency reserves announcements and HMRC's customs and excise guidance.
artifacts.teamBriefing:
Here is the team briefing with the requested sections and formatting:

Discussion Points
- Analyze the impact and urgency levels of the updates to determine which ones require the most immediate attention.
- Identify any updates that have a significant impact level and high urgency, as these will be the top priority.
- Review the updates related to consumer credit, motor finance, and compensation schemes, as these appear to be a key focus area.
- Examine the updates on crypto-asset regulation, financial crime prevention, and sanctions, as these are also important areas to monitor.
- Consider the implications of the updates on the financial services sectors represented, such as banking, investment management, payment services, and fintech.

Questions to Investigate
- What are the key compliance deadlines associated with the updates, and how will they impact the firm's operations?
- Are there any updates that require the firm to take specific actions, such as reporting, registration, or policy changes?
- How can the firm leverage the information in the updates to enhance its risk management and compliance frameworks?
- Are there any areas where the firm may need to seek further guidance or clarification from the regulators?
- What potential business impacts or opportunities may arise from the updates, and how can the firm position itself accordingly?

Resource Requirements
- Dedicated compliance and regulatory affairs team to closely monitor the updates and assess their implications.
- Access to legal and technical expertise to interpret the updates and their requirements.
- Sufficient budget and resources to implement any necessary changes or enhancements to the firm's compliance program.
- Effective communication channels to disseminate the update information to relevant business units and stakeholders.

Response Timeline
- Immediate: Review the updates with significant impact and high urgency, and develop a plan to address the most pressing compliance requirements.
- Short-term (1-3 months): Conduct a detailed analysis of all the updates, identify any actions required, and incorporate them into the firm's compliance roadmap.
- Ongoing: Establish a regular monitoring and review process to stay abreast of any new developments or changes to the updates.
- Quarterly: Assess the firm's progress in addressing the update requirements and make any necessary adjustments to the compliance strategy.
